data.title: Rupert Alexander George Augustus (Teck) Cambridge (1907-1928)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Compare DNA and explore genealogy for Rupert (Teck) Cambridge born 1907 Claremont House, Esher, Surrey, England died 1928 Belleville-sur-Saône, Rhône, Rhône-Alpes, France including ancestors + DNA connections + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors

Problems/Questions

Profile last modified 7 Dec 2021 | Created 4 Feb 2017

This page has been accessed 821 times.

Contents

1 Note

2 Biography

3 Sources

3.1 Footnotes

3.2 Acknowledgments

Note

The name fields for this profile follow the Euro Aristo naming standards. Please don't make any changes without referring to those standards and/or the profile manager. Thank you

Biography

He was born 24 August 1907 at Claremont House, Esher, Surrey in England, as His Serene Highness Prince Rupert Alexander George Augustus of Teck (in German Von Teck), the eldest son of HSH Prince Alexander of Teck, and Her Royal Highness Princess Alice of Albany.

His father was the fourth and youngest child of Francis (Franz), Prince and Duke of Teck, and his wife Princess Mary Adelaide of Cambridge, a granddaughter of King George III. Alexander's sister, Mary married King George V. Rupert's mother was the daughter of Prince Leopold, Duke of Albany, the fourth son of Queen Victoria, and his wife, Helene, Princess of Waldeck and Pyrmont. Leopold had died from the effects of haemophilia, and Rupert also suffered from this condition.

Prince Rupert was a haemophiliac, which he inherited through his mother from his great-grandmother, Queen Victoria, through his grandfather, the Duke of Albany who was also a haemophiliac.

At the request of King George V, Rupert's father relinquished for himself and his issue his German styles and titles and assumed by royal licence the surname of Cambridge on 14 July 1917. He was then created Earl of Athlone and Viscount Trematon in the county of Cambridge on 16 July. Rupert holding the courtesy title of Viscount Trematon from that date.

Rupert attended Trinity College, Cambridge. When his father, Alexander was bestowed the title, The Right Honourable, The Earl of Athlone; Rupert adopted the courtesy title of Viscount Trematon.

He had been educated at Eton, and Trinity College, Cambridge, but on 1 April 1928 at Belleville-sur-Saone, while on a motoring holiday in France, he swerved to avoid another vehicle and crashed into a tree. His passenger was killed and Rupert severely injured.

On April 1, 1928 Rupert was driving with two friends on the road from Paris to Lyon. While passing another car, Rupert's car hit a tree and flipped over. One friend died from injuries, Rupert was transported to a nearby hospital at Belleville-sur-Saône with a slight skull fracture. He died in hospital in the early hours of April 15, 1928 from an intracerebral hemorrhage. His funeral was held in St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle, and was attended by King George V and Queen Mary. He was buried in the Royal Burial Ground, Frogmore, on 20 April 1928. The title of Earl of Athlone became extinct in 1957 when his father died with no male predecessor to inherit it. His brother Maurice had died 18 years earlier as an infant, in 1910.

Sources

Bede Clifford, ‘Cambridge, Alexander Augustus Frederick William Alfred George, earl of Athlone (1874–1957)’, rev. Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, Jan 2011 accessed 18 Oct 2017

Wikipedia Profile: Rupert Cambridge, Viscount Trematon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rupert_Cambridge,_Viscount_Trematon : accessed 03 Feb 2017).

Find A Grave, database and images (accessed 18 January 2020), memorial page for Rupert Viscount Trematon (24 Apr 1907–15 Apr 1928), Find A Grave: Memorial #6137145, citing Royal Burial Ground, Windsor, Windsor and Maidenhead Royal Borough, Berkshire, England ; Maintained by Find A Grave .
